textline.text: Brandon Berry, PhD
UC Davis Medical Center, Education Building,
4610 X Street, Sacramento,
blberry@ucdavis.edu
2013 – 2016 Postdoctoral Fellow, University of California, Davis, School of Nursing
2012 – 2013 Postdoctoral Fellow, Duke University, Center for Aging and Human
Development
2012 PhD, Sociology, UCLA
Dissertation Title: Lost! The Social Psychology of Missing Possessions
Committee: Jack Katz (Chair), Stefan Timmermans, Robert Emerson,
Jason Throop (Anthropology)
2000 AB, Sociology, Occidental College, with Honors
Medical Sociology, Social Psychology, Science & Technology, Cognition & Memory,
Ethnography
Berry, Brandon, Ester Apesoa-Varano, Yarin Gomez. (2015). How family members
manage risk around functional decline: The autonomy management process in
households facing dementia. Social Science & Medicine. 130, 107-114
Berry, Brandon (2014). Minimizing confusion and disorientation: Cognitive support
work in dementia households. Journal of Aging Studies. 30, 121-130.
Berry, Brandon (2012). Reflections of self from missing things: How people move on
from losing possessions. The Annals of the American Academy of Political and
Social Science. 642 (1), 228-243.
Submitted
Berry, Brandon & Ester Apesoa-Varano. Medication takeovers: Regimen adjustment
work, covert druggings, and resistance in households facing Alzheimer’s.
Sociology of Health and Illness in June 2015.
Manuscripts in Prep.
Berry, Brandon & Ester Apesoa-Varano. Suspending disbelief: The cognitive work of
training with simulated human bodies in medical school. To be submitted to The
Sociology of Health and Illness.
Berry, Brandon & Ester Apesoa-Varano. Dummy Medicine: How American Doctors train
with Simulated Human Bodies. Book manuscript in prep.
Berry, Brandon. The informal economy of ideas: How scientists trade, gift, and protect
original thought in bench science. To be submitted to The American Journal of
Sociology.
Berry, Brandon. Credit sorting: The social psychology of authorship order in bench
science. To be submitted to Social Studies of Science.
Berry, Brandon. Paper-driven science: How the need to publish at a competitive pace
influences scientific work. To be submitted to Social Studies of Science.
Berry, Brandon. Lost! The Social Psychology of Missing Possessions. Book manuscript
in prep.
Berry, Brandon. Ordinary mystery: Meaning vacuums, perturbed existence, and
connecting the dots when something goes missing. To be submitted to Social
Psychology Quarterly.
Book Review
Berry, Brandon (2001). Review of the book Rites of Men: Manhood, Politics and the
Culture of Sport by Varda Burstyn. Journal of Men’s Studies. 9, 2.
Research in Progress
Berry, Brandon. The social psychology of scientific work. Planned data collection:
Observation in lab & collaboration meetings & 50 interviews with academic
scientists. Current status: Data collection, analysis, and writing phases.
Berry, Brandon & Ester Apesoa-Varano. Dummy medicine: How doctors train with
simulated human bodies. Planned data collection: 6 months of observation in a
simulation center at a medical school & 50 interviews with technicians, faculty,
and students. Current status: Data collection, analysis, and writing phases.
Conference Presentations and Guest Lectures_________________________________
4/15 “Giving medications to elders: Regimen takeovers, secretive druggings, and
resistance in households facing Alzheimer’s. UC Davis Medical Center, RCMAR
Poster Session.
10/14 “Cognitive decline and risk in dementia: A social control model,” UC Davis
Medical Center, Faculty Research Seminar.
8/14 “How families manage functional decline across disease progression: The
autonomy management process in dementia households, ASA Round Table
Presentation, San Francisco.
5/14 “Ethnographic Exercises for Doctoral Students in the Health Sciences,” Research
Methods Seminar, UC Davis Medical Center.
4/14 “Reducing the risks of incompetency: Autonomy management work in dementia
households.” Presentation at the UC Davis Medical Center Qualitative Health
Symposium.
2/14 “Dementia & Society Research Trajectory,” Invited Lecture, UC Davis School of
Nursing for Dean Heather Young.
12/13 “The Foundations and Practice of Ethnographic Research,” Invited Lecture, UC
Davis School of Nursing, for Prof. Elena Siegel.
3/13 “The Social Organization of Sudden Personality Change in Dementia,” Center for
the Study of Aging and Human Development, Duke University School of
Medicine.
6/12 “Turning Points in Commitment to a Misplaced Object,” Invited Lecture, Self and
Society Course, Jack Katz, UCLA
6/11 “Misremembering and Misplacement,” Invited Ethnography Conference
Presentation, Elijah Anderson, Yale University.
3/11 “Subjective Experiences of Memory: The Sociological Importance of
Psychological Phenomena,” Invited Lecture, Self and Society Course, Jack Katz,
UCLA.
11/10 “How Objects Become ‘Lost’: A Naturalistic Social Psychology,” Yale
University Ethnography Conference, Invited by Elijah Anderson.
8/08 “When Things Go Astray: Social Psychological Experiences of Misplacement and
Misremembering,” ASA Annual Meeting, Boston.
4/05 “Animated Modeling of Social Psychological Processes.” University of
Pennsylvania: Philadelphia Ethnography Project.
4/03 Section Presider: “Doing Fieldwork in Public Places,” Pacific Sociological
Association Meeting.

Sacramento

and Jack Katz)

and Jack Katz)

(w Jack Katz)
6/04-9/04 Research Assistant, Ethnic Stratification across Los Angeles (w Jack Katz)
1/04-3/04 Research Assistant, Analyzing Los Angeles Census Data (w Jack Katz)
1/03-3/03 Teaching Assistant, Development of Sociological Theory
9/02-12/02 Teaching Assistant, Development of Sociological Theory
2013-14 Postdoctoral Fellowship – Center for Aging and Human Development, Duke
University School of Medicine (Declined)
2012-14 Postdoctoral Fellowship – Institute for Health, Health Care Policy and Aging
Research - Rutgers University (Declined)

2005-06 Graduate Research Mentorship Award, UCLA

2004 Summer Mentorship Award for Independent Research, UCLA

UC Davis
